Introduction Sjögren's syndrome (SS) significantly elevates the risk of salivary gland lymphoma, primarily mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) type, arising within chronic lymphoepithelial sialadenitis (LESA). Benign lymphoepithelial cysts (BLECs), common in SS, can radiologically mimic malignancy, posing diagnostic challenges when occult lymphoma develops. Case presentation A 53-year-old woman with established SS developed progressive bilateral parotid enlargement over years. Initial ultrasonography and CT imaging revealed bilateral septated cysts, ductal calculi, and heterogeneous gland architecture, interpreted as benign inflammatory disease or sialolithiasis. Subtotal parotidectomy performed for cosmetic concerns on the larger side yielded histopathology confirming MALT lymphoma arising within LESA and BLECs. Discussion This case underscores the diagnostic dilemma of cystic parotid lesions in SS, where benign-appearing BLECs can harbor or be adjacent to occult MALT lymphoma. The malignant transformation highlights the inherent risk within chronic LESA. Imaging features of BLECs and cystic lymphoma often overlap; key discriminators like restricted diffusion on MRI warrant attention. Fine-needle aspiration has limitations, necessitating histopathological evaluation of tissue for definitive diagnosis, especially with persistent gland enlargement. Conclusion Persistent or progressive parotid enlargement in SS, even with cystic features suggestive of benign disease, necessitates a high index of suspicion for occult lymphoma. Histopathological verification remains paramount for accurate diagnosis and timely intervention, emphasizing the critical need for integrated clinical, radiological, and pathological assessment in these high-risk patients. Highlights • SS-associated MALT lymphoma can lurk within seemingly benign parotid cysts (BLECs), easily misleading initial imaging like US/CT. • Only removal of the tissue and histopathology reliably diagnoses occult lymphoma; FNA often misses monoclonality in cystic SS lesions. • SS patients face a 13.76-fold lifetime salivary lymphoma risk. Persistent gland swelling demands suspicion, even with "benign" imaging. • Chronic lymphoepithelial sialadenitis (LESA) in SS harbors significant malignant potential, evolving into MALT lymphoma within cystic structures. • Managing cystic parotid lesions in SS requires combining clinical suspicion, advanced MRI (DWI/ADC), and definitive histopathology to catch transformation. This case underscores the diagnostic complexity of cystic parotid lesions in SS, highlights the malignant potential of LESA, and reinforces the necessity for histopathological vigilance in patients with progressive glandular enlargement. 2 Methods This work is also reported in line with SCARE criteria which helped to improve the transparency and quality of this case report [ 8 3 Case presentation A 53-year-old woman presented seven years ago with symptoms of arthritis, dry eyes, and dry mouth, consistent with Sjögren's syndrome. Initially, she was managed with daily Prednisolone 5 mg and hydroxychloroquine 200 mg. She has no history of smoking or alcohol consumption. Over time, she developed gradual bilateral swelling of the parotid glands ( Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Fig. 1 Bilateral parotid gland swelling. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 A contrast-enhanced CT scan demonstrated multiple cysts of varying sizes within the parotid glands. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The salivary gland tissue is almost completely obscured by diffuse small lymphocytic infiltrate with focal germinal centers. Although the overall lobular architecture is still preserved, the lymphoid infiltrate focally overruns epithelial nests with monocytoid features. CD20 shows diffuse positivity on lymphoid cells, almost exclusively, also highlighting prominent intraepithelial lymphocytes. Fig. 3 4 Discussion This case of Sjögren's syndrome ( SS 1 1 4 5 2 4 6 1 4 3 5 9 3 6 2 10 The pathogenesis involves chronic antigenic stimulation driving B-cell proliferation in SS, with eventual clonal expansion and genetic aberrations (e.g., trisomy 3, t(11;18)) culminating in MALT lymphoma [ 1 2 7 3 6 1 4 3 6 2 7 3 This case exemplifies the distinct predilection of SS-associated lymphomagenesis for MALT histotype, as non-MALT subtypes show negligible association with SS (0 % prevalence in meta-analysis) [ 1 3 6 1 4 1 3 Cystic parotid lesions in SS represent a continuum from benign LESA to overt lymphoma. This case exemplifies the imperative for rigorous, longitudinal evaluation of such patients, integrating clinical, radiological, and pathological insights to intercept malignant transformation early. 5 Conclusion This case of bilateral MALT lymphoma arising within parotid BLECs in a Sjögren's syndrome patient underscores the significant diagnostic challenge posed by cystic parotid lesions in this autoimmune context. It vividly illustrates the inherent malignant potential of chronic lymphoepithelial sialadenitis (LESA) and the critical limitations of relying solely on imaging findings suggestive of benign disease. Persistent or progressive glandular enlargement in SS, even with cystic features initially managed as benign, demands a high index of suspicion for occult lymphoma. Histopathological evaluation of excised tissue remains the indispensable gold standard for definitive diagnosis and timely intervention, emphasizing the need for vigilant, integrated clinical-radiological-pathological assessment in these high-risk patients to intercept malignant transformation.
